awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Mediated Orthopedic Implant Design and Selection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is customized dental implant solutions for animals affected by traumatic jaw injury and disease. Current veterinary implants utilize platforms designed for human use, despite a greater variability in anatomy, bone strength, and procedural requirements. This approach has subsequent shortcomings accounting for anatomical and physiologic variations resulting in trauma, neovascular damage, incomplete healing, and failure to improve or restore functionality. The project proposes a software program and system for generating customized implant designs and criteria based on the specific anatomy and procedure. A successful project would improve veterinary care and the lives of pets and service dogs following injury. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a Machine Learning (ML) software to incorporate bone density screening with 2-dimensional to 3-dimensional reconstruction software to create anatomically derived implants and software guided implant placement. The proposed ML system will identify key anatomical considerations and animal classifications for optimizing implant designs and procedural criteria. By integrating a database of appropriate animal scans, the ML software will identify the optimal regions for implant and refine as needed. The result of this Phase 1 is a database-derived algorithm which generates implant shapes and sizes that avoid anatomical features that interfere with proper placement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF SBIR Phase I project aimed to revolutionize veterinary orthopedic surgery by developing AI-driven solutions for implant design and selection, specifically targeting mandibular surgeries in canines. The project has broader applications, expanding to long bones, hips, and other anatomical areas. The primary goal was to streamline and automate the design and placement of surgical implants by leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies.

Intellectual Merit:
Our team successfully trained advanced AI algorithms, including an Attention U-Net model, capable of isolating complex anatomical structures such as the mandible, teeth, and nerves from veterinary CT scans. These models were designed to assist veterinary surgeons by improving implant placement accuracy and minimizing risks. Additionally, a trajectory planning system was created to help surgeons place screws in optimal positions while avoiding critical structures. The AI’s ability to predict screw trajectories has shown great potential to outperform traditional manual methods in precision and safety.Through this project, we demonstrated the capability of AI technologies to not only increase the accuracy of surgical planning but also to automate the design of personalized implants. This innovation has the potential to enhance both the quality and efficiency of veterinary care, ultimately benefiting animals in need of complex surgeries.

Broader Impacts:
The project has far-reaching implications beyond veterinary care. The AI tools we developed can be applied to various orthopedic procedures, such as correcting angular limb deformities and total hip arthroplasty. The technology has already attracted the attention of industry leaders for the purposes of potential commercialization.From a societal perspective, our work has the potential to improve the standard of care for animals undergoing complex surgeries, leading to faster recovery times and better surgical outcomes. Additionally, the methodologies we developed can be extended to human healthcare, potentially improving surgical precision in orthopedic and dental surgeries. The AI models and trajectory planning system could also help reduce surgical times, lower risks, and standardize procedures across different veterinary and human medical practices.This project also contributed to the training and professional development of researchers, veterinarians, and engineers, providing hands-on experience with AI technologies and medical imaging techniques. Collaborative efforts with veterinary schools and industry partners have fostered an interdisciplinary approach, further enhancing the impact of our work.In conclusion, the project outcomes not only demonstrate significant advancements in AI-driven veterinary surgical planning but also pave the way for future innovations in both veterinary and human medical fields. With a strong foundation in AI and surgical planning, this technology is poised to make a significant commercial and societal impact.


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: William Byron
